_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response:

Wynnewood Refining Company (WRC) is required to follow the Process Safety Management Program under OSHA, and as such, has conducted audits in all the affected units.  WRC has also developed an emergency response plan to handle both on-site and off-site emergencies.

B.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Wynnewood Refining Company is a fully integrated petroleum refinery.  The main products are gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, hydrocarbon solvents, liquefied petroleum gases and asphalts.  The covered processes considered for the RMP are as follows:

1)  HF Alkylation Unit - This unit, which includes an olefin treater, converts olefin and isobutane into gasoline using HF acid as a catalyst.  

2)  Liquified Petroleum Gases - This is an LPG storage, loading and unloading facility.  It contains 24 tanks that typically contain about 3,000,000 lbs of butane, 1-butene, 2-butene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, isobutane, propane, and propylene.

3)  Fluid Catalytic Cracking Unit/Gas Con Unit - The FCCU/Gas Con unit processes gas oils into LPGs, gasoline, distillate, and slurry oil.  

4)  Crude Distillation - Crude distillation processes crude oil into LPGs, gasoline, diesel, naphtha, gas oils, and vacuum unit charge.  

5)  ROSE Unit - The ROSE unit extracts gas oils from vacuum asphalts using butane as a solvent.  The ROSE unit normally contains about 73,000 lbs of butane.

6)  LSR Hydrotreater - The Light Straight Run Hydrotreater converts pentane into isopentane.  

7)  Hydrotreater - This unit converts light cycle oil and diesel type charge stocks into gasoline and lighter products.  

8)  Platformer - The platformer converts low octane and straight chain naphtha into high-octane gasoline.  

9)  Naphtha Hydrotreater - This unit removes sulfur from the naphtha charge to the platformer.  

10) Gasoline Hydrotreater - This unit removes sulfur from FCC naphtha to reduce gasoline sulfur content.

C.  The Worst-Case Scenarios and Alternative Scenarios:

The worst-case scenario for a toxic release was determined to be a release of 90,000 lbs of hydrofluoric acid from the settler vessel in the HF alkylation unit.  The distance to the endpoint, using the OSC analysis, was determined to be 12 miles.  No other toxics were found in the WRC facility that exceeded the threshold quantity.

The worst-case scenario for a flammable release was determined to be a release of 448,253 lbs of isobutane resulting from the failure of an LPG storage tank.  The distance to a 1-psi overpressure, using the OSC analysis, was determined to be 0.47 miles.

The alternate case scenario for a toxic release was determined to be the failure of a 4-inch valve on the settler vessel in the HF alkylation unit but with the deluge system knocking down the HF acid vapors.  The distance to endpoint was determined to be 0.43 miles.

The alternate case scenario for a flammable release was determined to be a release of 206,196 lbs of isobutane.  The distance to the 1-psi overpressure was determined to be 0.31 miles. 

D.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program & Chemical Prevention Steps:

WRC operators visually check their equipment to look for deterioration and signs of leakage.  If a problem is found, the unit undergoes a thorough repair and inspection.  In addition, all process units undergo scheduled shutdown, cleaning and inspection, with repair of any problems found.  Employees, as well as emergency response personnel, including off-site doctors and hospital staffs, have been informed as to what chemicals WRC uses and procedures to minimize effects from exposures.

E.  Five Year Accident History:

During the past five years, this facility has had one release (see Section 6 of this RMP submittal) of a regulated substance under these rules that resulted in significant property damage on site and offsite evacuations.  The release did not result in any deaths or injuries on site, or known o

ffsite deaths, injuries, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  At approximately 2:15 P.M. on May 12, 2006, there was an explosion and subsequent fire at the refinery's alkylation unit.  In addition to the fire, the event included an HF acid release.  The initial fire and HF acid release were controlled, but intermittent controlled releases occurred until May 21, 2006.  The total amount of HF released over the period was estimated at 4900 pounds.  

F.  Emergency Response Program:

WRC has prepared an emergency response plan which describes the response actions to be taken during on-site and off-site emergencies.  The plan provides for emergency response, preparedness, and prevention and fulfills those requirements under a number of different regulatory programs to which the refinery is subject.

G.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

WRC thoroughly investigates all incidents under the OSHA and PSM regulations and implements recommendations resulting from the investigations.
